Description: Body sherd (mended from two fragments) with handle root of South Ionian pottery cup, probably a cup with everted rim; interior: alternating black and reserved bands, the latter with a single dilute line; exterior: handle zone reserved, glazed below with two reserved bands.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2 (possibly)
Curator's comments: The sherd joins British Museum 1965,0930..624 and probably belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1965,0930.623 and 1965,0930.622. The lack of a rim prevents a definitive identification of the cup as a South Ionian cup with everted rim. However, the sherd may belong to the same vase as British Museum 1965,0930.622, whose profile and interior decoration find parallels with Hayes' Ionian Cup Type VIII (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116). Hayes' Type VIII is of the same shape as his Type IX (only the interior decoration is different) which coincides with Schlotzhauer's (Schlotzhauer 2012) Type 9A. The type closely follows the shape and decoration of the Attic Plain Komast cups. These cups coincide with Petrie’s class L1 (Petrie 1886, 18) and Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88). Type 9 cups have been found in large numbers in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus and the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra. This type was the most common type of South Ionian cups with everted rims found at Naukratis. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.298) (Phase 3)
